posts.title: Confessions of a Black Comic Book Festival Cosplayer: Michael Flood’s Impromptu Idea With a Fellow Cosplayer Helped Start a Festival Tradition
posts.text: Actor Michael Flood shares his experiences as a Black Comic Book Festival cosplayer at the festival celebrates its 10th anniversary.

posts.title: 2022 Preview: Upcoming Events at the Schomburg Center
posts.text: Find out what’s happening in-person and virtually from January through April 2022 at the Schomburg Center.

posts.title: Back to the Beginning: How Tim Fielder Got His Start with the Black Comic Book Festival
posts.text: As the Schomburg Center celebrates the 10th anniversary of the BCBF in January 2022, Fielder shares what inspired him to first attend, what the festivals mean to him, and how they changed the trajectory of his career.

posts.title: The Black Comic Book Festival Is Turning 10!
posts.text: As the countdown to the 2022 Black Comic Book Festival begins, enjoy a look back with this seven-part blog series.The articles offer a glimpse into some of the many people who are part of BCBF’s history. Plus, get an overview of the Schomburg Center’s comic book and graphic novel collections to learn even more.

posts.title: 4 Black Comic Book Festival Talks You Should Watch Before the 2022 Festival
posts.text: Kadiatou Tubman has been the lead producer of the festival since 2017. Here, she recommends four talks from past festivals to watch as you await the upcoming event.

posts.title: After the Pandemic Legacies Conference: Continue the Learning on Medicine
posts.text: If the virtual conference Pandemic Legacies inspired further interest in learning about Black wellness, here's a list of some of our online and in-person materials to add to the conversation.

posts.title: Reflection and Remembrance: The African Burial Ground, 30 Years After Discovery
posts.text: Two Schomburg Center volunteers, who took part in the grassroots efforts to save the African Burial Ground, look back at this historic effort 30 years later.

posts.title: Program Schedule for Pandemic Legacies Conference
posts.text: See our list of programs and speakers for our 2021 Conference Pandemic Legacies: Health, Healing, and Medicine in the Age of Slavery and Beyond

posts.title: What's Happening at the Schomburg Center: Fall 2021 Preview
posts.text: We hope to see you at the programs happening (virtually and in-person) at the Schomburg Center in the upcoming months.

posts.title: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month and Afro-Latinx Ties
posts.text: Many people of Hispanic descent also have African roots. Explore the Schomburg Center’s collections and Livestream archive to learn of the rich history, deep ties, and political challenges between both communities. Plus, learn more about materials once owned by Arturo Schomburg, which highlight his Puerto Rican and African heritages.

posts.title: Champions for Equality On and Off the Tennis Courts
posts.text: Inspired by the US Open to learn more about tennis champions Althea Gibson and Arthur Ashe? They both have collections at the Schomburg Center. Consider making a research appointment to explore their materials.

posts.title: Celebrate Harlem Week!
posts.text: Explore Schomburg Center collections and exhibitions which highlight the history, artists, leaders and events that have shaped Harlem and influenced the world.

posts.title: Explore the Schomburg Center Collections with Our Summer Music Mash-Up
posts.text: Check out these suggestions of music-related materials you can see in-person when you make a research appointment at one of our five divisions, plus explore our exhibitions.

posts.title: Courtroom Battles for Justice: Garvey, Holiday, and Davis
posts.text: Throughout American history, law enforcement and those with racial prejudices have weaponized the law in attempts to imprison, punish, and silence Black people. Using the Schomburg Center’s resources, learn about past court cases that have impacted the Black community and activists, and how they responded.

posts.title: Continue Conversations from the 2021 Schomburg Center Literary Festival
posts.text: Use Schomburg Center materials to continue the conversations on the concepts of freedom, which were raised during panel discussion during the 2021 Schomburg Center Literary Festival.

posts.title: Research Guides to Expand Conversations from the Schomburg Center's Youth Summit
posts.text: Entitled 'Til We Free, the day reflected students' yearlong exploration of African diasporic history, politics, literature, and art.

posts.title: Courtroom Battles for Justice: Seeking Equity and Accountability
posts.text: Throughout American history, law enforcement and those with racial prejudices have weaponized the law in attempts to imprison, punish, and silence Black people. Using the Schomburg Center’s resources, learn about past court cases that have impacted the Black community and activists, and how they responded.

posts.title: Feed Your Mind & Nourish Your Soul on Earth Day
posts.text: Earth Day, which promotes protecting the environment, is on April 22. The day can also be a starting point on discussions such as climate change, environmental racism, agriculture, and more. Zakiya Collier, digital archivist in our Manuscripts, Archives, and Rare Books Division, and Michael Mery, acting curator of our Photographs and Prints Division, share digital resources to help spark those conversations.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center: Public Programs
posts.text: Novella Ford, associate director of Public Programs and Exhibitions, share her picks of Livestream talks to watch.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center
posts.text: The Schomburg Center has over 1,100 digitized collections and 300 Livestream programs online. Curators, librarians, and staff share their picks of materials to explore.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center: Art & Artifacts
posts.text: Tammi Lawson, curator of the Art & Artifacts Division, shares her pick of a Schomburg Center digital collection to explore.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center: Education
posts.text: Dr. Brian Jones, associate director of Schomburg Educational Programs, shares his suggestions for compelling education content including projects by the Junior Scholars and Teen Curators programs.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center: Research and Reference Division
posts.text: Staff of the Jean Blackwell Hutson Research Research and Reference Division suggest some highlights of the collections to explore.

posts.title: Recommended by the Schomburg Center: Lapidus Center
posts.text: Dr. Michelle Commander shares her picks of Schomburg Center digital collections and Livestream conversations to explore.

posts.title: Recommended By The Schomburg Center: Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books
posts.text: Cheryl Beredo, curator of the Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division, and Digital Archivist Zakiya Collier share their picks of digital collections to explore.

posts.title: Recommended By the Schomburg Center: Photographs & Prints
posts.text: Michael Mery, acting curator of the Photographs and Prints Division, shares his picks of digital collections to explore.

posts.title: Black Women Writers in Arturo Schomburg’s Collection
posts.text: In celebration of Women's History month, learn about some of the books featuring Black women writers in Arturo Schomburg's Collection. Digital replicas are available to read via the HathiTrust Digital Library.

posts.title: Arturo Schomburg Featured in Jeopardy! Answer
posts.text: This past November, Arturo Schomburg popped up in an answer on the popular TV game show.

posts.title: Schomburg Curator Releases Two Books in One Month
posts.text: 'Unsung' and 'Avidly Reads: Passages,' edited and written by Dr. Michelle Commander, respectively, will be released this month. Find out how Dr. Commander juggled both projects simultaneously, plus co-curated a reading list with Penguin Classics.

posts.title: A Digital Glimpse Into Arturo Schomburg’s Collections
posts.text: Explore the HathiTrust Digital Library, NYPL, and the Schomburg Center’s digital collections to read copies of the books similar to ones in Mr. Schomburg’s collection.

posts.title: A Look at the Ella Baker Initiative & Intergenerational Activism
posts.text: Zenzele Johnson, manager of the Ella Baker Initiative at the Schomburg Center, discusses the project and its mission to inspire civic engagement in the tradition of its namesake. Plus, Johnson talks about a family tradition she unwittingly continued during the 2020 election.

posts.title: Protests, Prose, Photos, & Continued Progress
posts.text: The year 2020 brought renewed attention to the fight for racial justice and equality. Explore the Schomburg Center’s digital collections, guides, and reading recommendations for a deeper understanding of the history, literature, and culture of the Black experience.

posts.title: Schomburg Center’s Malcolm X Collection Supports Award-Winner
posts.text: 'The Dead Are Arising: The Life of Malcolm X' by Les Payne and Tamara Payne won the National Book Award’s 2020 nonfiction prize. Explore the Schomburg Center’s and NYPL’s Digital Collections to learn more about the book and the authors.

posts.title: Schomburg Center Honors Life and Legacy of David N. Dinkins
posts.text: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture honors the life of David N. Dinkins, who passed away on Monday, November 23, at age 93. Mr. Dinkins was New York City’s 106th mayor and made history in 1990 as the first African American elected to the position.

posts.title: Schomburg Center Celebrates Hip Hop History Month
posts.text: November is Hip Hop History Month. Explore the Schomburg Center's collections to learn about the artists and writers who created and nurtured the art form.

posts.title: As You Get Ready To Cast Your Vote...
posts.text: As you consider all of the issues and get ready to cast your vote, catch up on the Schomburg Center's and NYPL's digital materials.

posts.title: Black Women Front and Center and Behind-the-Scenes in Politics
posts.text: Black women fought to secure all women's right to vote, advocated for racial justice and equality, and pushed back against voter suppression. Explore the digital collections to learn about legendary women such as Ella Baker and Mary McLeod Bethune and current voices such as Carol Anderson and Patrisse Cullors.

posts.title: Schomburg Center Literary Festival Returns
posts.text: Get ready for a book lovers feast! Join us for virtual readings and panel discussions for all ages and genres, ranging from prose to poetry, comic books to young adult novels, fiction and nonfiction.

posts.title: Take a Deep Dive into the Black Liberation Reading List
posts.text: Explore talks by some of these authors on the Schomburg Center's Livestream channel.

posts.title: Postage Stamps Honor Scholars and Novelist in Schomburg Center Collections
posts.text: The bibliophile, the poet, the “Dean,” and the novelist—their work in the 1920s helped shape the course of art, academics, and literature for generations.

posts.title: Selections from the Schomburg Shop
posts.text: Michelle Alexander's 'The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness', Claudia Rankine's 'Citizen: American Lyric', and James Baldwin's 'The Fire Next Time' are some of the books on the Schomburg Center’s Black Liberation Reading List.
